bioghist.p: The Pennsylvania Horticultural Society is Americaâ€™s first horticultural society and was formed in 1827 as a not-for-profit membership organization. The Pennsylvania Horticultural Society offers lectures and workshops, publishes the magazine Green Scene, and hosts the yearly Philadelphia Flower Show. First held in 1829, the Philadelphia Flower Show has grown to be the world's largest indoor flower exhibition. Proceeds from the Philadelphia Flower Show support the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society's urban greening program, Philadelphia Green, which supports the development and ongoing care of community gardens, neighborhood parks and high-profile public green spaces in Philadelphia. The Pennsylvania Horticultural Society is also home to the McLean Library, a collection of over 15,000 books on gardening and plant care, botany, and urban greening.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of artifacts and memorabilia related to the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society and the Philadelphia Flower Show. Items include: a Pennsylvania Horticultural Society member's ceramic mug from 2006; a 1995 18th Century Garden ornament and two 1994 Poinsettia glass Christmas ornaments, accompanied by advertisements from Green Scene describing the ornaments; sets of notecards depicting plates from Robert Thornton's Temple of Flora and other horticultural images; and a seal of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society. Flower Show artifacts include: two seals from Philadelphia Flower Show, Inc.; a brass plaque from the Flower Show; a cloth banner from the 175th anniversary Flower Show in 2004; two keepsake ceramic rose figurines made by Boehm for the Philadelphia Flower Show; and a silver cup awarded by the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society to Jonathan Sherwood for his Camellia Isabell Hartley and a published biography of Sarah Palmer Sherwood The collection also includes approximately 25 medals awarded to individuals by the society for horticultural achievements and by other gardening associations to the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society. Medal recipients include Caleb Cope and James Boyd.
